Problem:
Consider a system governed by the partial differential equation \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = Lu\\), where L is a linear differential operator. We look into the effect of applying a Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F}(u)(\\xi) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} e^{-2\\pi i x \\xi} u(x) dx \\) to the function u(x, t) and analyzing its effect over time t.

If \\( \\mathcal{F}(u(x, 0)) \\) is computed at t = 0 and then u(x, t) is allowed to evolve under \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = Lu\\) without further intervention, will the Fourier transform of u(x, T) for some T > 0 be equal to e^{LT} \\mathcal{F}(u(x, 0))?
Explanation: The evolution of u(x, t) under the PDE followed by the Fourier transform yields \\( \\mathcal{F}(u(x, T)) = e^{LT} \\mathcal{F}(u(x, 0)) \\) based on the properties of L and the Fourier transform being a linear operation. Hence, the transformation acts consistently with the linear dynamics of the PDE.
